articles.headline: Pursuing U.S. Aid, G.M. Accepts Need for Drastic Cuts
articles.snippet: General Motors said it needed an $18 billion package in loans and lines of credit and that it will cut jobs, factories, brands and executive pay.
articles.abstract: General Motors said it needed an $18 billion package in loans and lines of credit and that it will cut jobs, factories, brands and executive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  General Motors, increasingly desperate for a federal bailout to stave off financial collapse, told Congress on Tuesday that it was willing to drastically shrink every aspect of its operations to ensure its long-term survival.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Another Month of Miserable Auto Sales
articles.snippet: In the worst month yet in a horrible year, U.S. sales fell 41 percent at General Motors and 33.9 percent at Toyota. Honda’s sales declined 31.6 percent, and Ford’s fell 30.6 percent.
articles.abstract: In the worst month yet in a horrible year, U.S. sales fell 41 percent at General Motors and 33.9 percent at Toyota. Honda’s sales declined 31.6 percent, and Ford’s fell 30.6 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Big Three automakers are scrambling to adjust their businesses to the reality of the market. But that reality is turning harsher by the month.

articles.headline: Cleveland Clinic Discloses Doctors’ Industry Ties
articles.snippet: In the first such step by a major medical center, the clinic says it has begun publicly disclosing the business relationships its staff has with drug makers.
articles.abstract: In the first such step by a major medical center, the clinic says it has begun publicly disclosing the business relationships its staff has with drug makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Clinic plans to announce this week it has begun publicly reporting the business relationships that any of its 1,800 staff doctors and scientists have with drug and device makers.

articles.headline: UnitedHealth to Insure the Right to Insurance
articles.snippet: The company will sell the right to buy an individual health policy in the future even if you become sick.
articles.abstract: The company will sell the right to buy an individual health policy in the future even if you become sick.
articles.lead_paragraph: For these economically uncertain times, the UnitedHealth Group has a “first of its kind” product: the right to buy an individual health policy at some point in the future even if you become sick.

articles.headline: After Sharp Words on C.I.A., Obama Faces a Delicate Task
articles.snippet: The president-elect must take charge of the agency in what is proving to be one of the more treacherous patches of the transition.
articles.abstract: The president-elect must take charge of the agency in what is proving to be one of the more treacherous patches of the transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For two years on the presidential campaign trail, Barack Obama rallied crowds with strongly worded critiques of the Bush administration’s most controversial counterterrorism programs, from hiding terrorism suspects in secret Central Intelligence Agency jails to questioning them with methods he denounced as torture.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Contrite Over Misstep, Auto Chiefs Take to Road
articles.snippet: The chief executives of Detroit’s Big Three, who took a drubbing for flying on private jets to Washington last month for a Congressional hearing, will be driving to get to the capital this time.
articles.abstract: The chief executives of Detroit’s Big Three, who took a drubbing for flying on private jets to Washington last month for a Congressional hearing, will be driving to get to the capital this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the fate of the United States auto industry hangs in the balance, a profound question has taken center stage: what about the planes?

articles.headline: Budgets Behaving Badly
articles.snippet: Behavioral economists offer insight that could be of use to the Obama administration as it works to devise a long-term plan to reduce deficits.
articles.abstract: Behavioral economists offer insight that could be of use to the Obama administration as it works to devise a long-term plan to reduce deficits.

articles.headline: Even in Michigan, Not Everyone Wants a Lifeline
articles.snippet: Many people in Michigan said in interviews that they could no longer see why the Big Three should be singled out for rescue.
articles.abstract: Many people in Michigan said in interviews that they could no longer see why the Big Three should be singled out for rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich.  Wander Michigan’s cities and towns, and many residents offer the same message about the prospect of a $34 billion bailout of America’s automakers: Please provide the help, not just for the sake of the automobile industry and its workers but for all the other people whose jobs are so intricately braided into the state’s autocentric economy.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: Harvard Endowment Loses 22%
articles.snippet: University officials have been told to expect a 30 percent drop in the endowment’s value because of the financial turmoil.
articles.abstract: University officials have been told to expect a 30 percent drop in the endowment’s value because of the financial turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of the economic times, Harvard has sent a letter to its deans saying that the university’s $36.9 billion endowment fund lost 22 percent of its value in the last four months and could decline as much as 30 percent by the end of the fiscal year on June 30.
